title: Information Disclosure - X-Powered-By Header Exposes Technology Stack
description: The application reveals the PHP version through the X-Powered-By header in HTTP responses. The header shows: X-Powered-By: PHP/7.4.33, which explicitly discloses that the application is running PHP 7.4.33. Additionally, the Server header discloses Apache/2.4.54 (Debian). This information helps attackers identify known vulnerabilities in the specific PHP and Apache versions and develop targeted exploits. The X-Powered-By header appears in all HTTP responses from the application, providing consistent exposure of the technology stack.
impact: This information disclosure helps attackers in reconnaissance. Knowing the specific PHP version (7.4.33) and Apache version (2.4.54) allows attackers to research known vulnerabilities, zero-days, CVEs, and develop more targeted attack strategies. Combined with version information disclosed in error pages, attackers have a complete picture of the technology stack to research and exploit known vulnerabilities in those specific versions. While this alone is not a critical vulnerability, it significantly aids in the reconnaissance phase of a targeted attack.
evidence:
HTTP GET request to http://localhost:8080/search.php returns response headers:
```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Fri, 07 Nov 2025 18:46:12 GMT
Server: Apache/2.4.54 (Debian)
X-Powered-By: PHP/7.4.33
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
```

The X-Powered-By header explicitly discloses PHP/7.4.33, and the Server header reveals Apache/2.4.54 (Debian). These headers are sent in all responses from the application, providing consistent technology stack information to potential attackers.
remediation:
1. Disable the X-Powered-By header in php.ini by setting: expose_php = Off
2. Remove the X-Powered-By header via .htaccess with: Header unset X-Powered-By
3. Suppress Server header information in Apache configuration by setting: ServerTokens Prod (only shows "Apache")
4. Consider using: ServerSignature Off to further minimize technology stack disclosure
5. Test that headers are properly removed after configuration changes using curl -I or similar tools
6. Implement a WAF or reverse proxy to filter or sanitize response headers before they reach clients
references: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor, OWASP A01:2021 - Broken Access Control, OWASP Top 10 2021 - A01:2021 Broken Access Control
toolCallDescription: Documenting unique finding: X-Powered-By header disclosing PHP version with working POC
